overview: Students enrolled in this subject will be matched individually by the Subject Coordinator to a media organisation suited to the student's interests, ambitions and skills, for a 20 day (or FTE) placement as an intern. Subject Coordinator will liaise with workplace mentor/supervisor to ensure student's internship is productive. The internship will facilitate the application of knowledge acquired through coursework to a professional workplace. The internship will stretch the student, provide a valuable professional experience , result in published work for the student's resume, and will extend professional networks.

necessary pre-requisite: Students will receive outcomes within two weeks of the closing date for the relevant round. For further information including FAQS on the Application and Selection Process see:
additional pre-requisite: Students must meet all of the following:
Admission into or selection of one of the following:MC-JOURN Master of JournalismMC-INTJOUR Master of International Journalism
This subject should be completed during the second half of the course
A grade point average over 70 in the subjects completed as part of current Masters.
Students are required to apply for permission to enrol into this subject prior to commencement of the internship. Students should make this application via the online application form:
Applications will be reviewed in three rounds:
Round 1 (Summer and Semester 1 availability): closing 31 October

assessments.description: A project proposal and work plan, developed in consultation with the host organisation and the Subject Coordinator, due within two weeks of beginning the internship.. 1000 words
assessments.timing: due within two weeks of beginning the internship.

assessments.description: A portfolio of work for the host organisation or equivalent in audio visual or multimedia material, to be assessed by the Subject Coordinator, in consultation with the host organisation, due within two weeks of the conclusion of the internship.. 2500 words (equivalent)
assessments.timing: due within two weeks of the conclusion of the internship.

assessments.description: A journal or reflective essay that documents and reflects on the Internship Experience, to be assessed by the Subject Coordinator, due within two weeks of the conclusion of the internship.. 1500 words
assessments.timing: due within two weeks of the conclusion of the internship.

assessments.description: Hurdle requirement:. 1. Students are required to attend a minimum of 80% of placement and supervisory meetings in order to pass the subject.

Hurdle requirement:. 2. Late Penalty and Assessment hurdle requirement: Assessment submitted late without an approved extension will be penalised at five per cent (5%) of the possible marks available for the assessment task per day or part thereof. All pieces of assessment must be submitted to pass the subject.  Each submitted assessment must be complete, constitute a genuine attempt to address the requirements of the task and will not be accepted after 20 University business days from the original assessment due date without written approval.

Semester 1.Contact hours: 20 days placement: Occasional academic supervision before, during and after the placement, to be determined in consultation with the Course Director.

Semester 2.Contact hours: 20 days placement: Occasional academic supervision before, during and after the placement, to be determined in consultation with the Course Director.

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.

This subject has a workplace component: Semester-long internship subject. Students enrolled in this subject will complete a four week (full time equivalent) placement with an external organisation.
